awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Focused Ion Beam Scanning Electron Microscope for Research in Advanced Materials, Energy, and Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:

The project is to acquire a dual-beam focused ion beam integrated with scanning electron microscope (FIB-SEM) to support research and education at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology and in the surrounding region. The system combines nanoscale materials patterning and processing with high-resolution imaging and analytical capabilities. The system will enable high resolution characterization, manipulation, and nanofabrication of metals, ceramics, and polymers. The system will provide an immediate and significant impact to research activities at the host institution and in the region. The instrumentation will also support training programs and will impact regional economic development by supporting local small enterprises. It will be integrated into outreach activities to broaden participation in STEM by students from underrepresented groups. Operation and maintenance of the system will be managed by the Engineering and Mining Experiment Station. EMES is a multi-user facility that serves universities and tribal colleges in South Dakota as well as regional enterprises, and state, tribal, and federal governments.

Technical:

The FIB-SEM will enable numerous new materials research capabilities that will support an exciting era of research growth in South Dakota. Coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and electron backscatter diffraction detectors, the system will permit high resolution chemical and crystallographic analysis of advanced materials. The FIB capability will also enable tomographic imaging and analysis of metals, ceramics, polymers, and biological materials (e.g., 3D imaging of multi-enzyme complexes that mediate microbial cell attachment for efficient biomass degradation). More than 35 faculty from SD’s three research institutions (SDSMT, South Dakota State University, and the University of South Dakota), multiple primarily undergraduate universities (e.g., Black Hills State University), and two tribal colleges (Oglala Lakota College, Sinte Gleska University) are expected to use the system for research and educational activities. The FIB-SEM will also impact seven active institutional and state-wide research centers/laboratories, the majority of which are focused in the area of advanced materials and manufacturing. The new equipment will complement previous MRI-funded equipment acquisitions that together will comprise a growing state-of-the-art materials characterization multi-user facility (EMES) that will positively impact SDSMT’s ability to competitively recruit talented faculty and students from underrepresented groups in STEM.  The FIB-SEM will support capstone engineering design projects and will be integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses at SDSMT, impacting 290 students on an annual basis. Further, a new course will be introduced to train students on the theory and application of FIB-SEM for advanced materials characterization. The FIB-SEM will be integrated into graduate and undergraduate research training programs, including two NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) Site programs and a recently funded NSF National Research Traineeship program. Regarding the former, the system will support a research project that involves cultural and scientific analysis of Native American (NA) artifacts, conducted as part of a REU program to facilitate engagement and training of NA students in STEM research. The FIB-SEM will also be integrated into ongoing STEM outreach programs intended to engage SD’s large NA population (including K-12 students/teachers and tribal college faculty and students) to increase awareness and access of the FIB-SEM for this underserved population. Finally, the system will support multiple regional tech-based start-up companies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Through the NSF MRI program the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT) acquired a dual-beam focused ion beam-scanning electron microscope (FIB-SEM). The system has provided an immediate and significant impact to both ongoing and planned research activities at SDSMT, and across the state of South Dakota (SD). The FIB-SEM replaced SDSMT’s previous SEM—a system beyond its usable life and the only SEM on campus—while also enabling numerous new capabilities (e.g. FIB nanofabrication and imaging) that have supported an exciting era of research growth. The FIB-SEM has also (i) facilitated recruitment of diverse and talented faculty and students, (ii) supported educational and research training programs, (iii) has been integrated into STEM outreach activities to broaden participation from underrepresented groups, and (iv) benefited regional economic development by supporting local tech-based small businesses.

Intellectual Merit

The FIB-SEM combines state-of-the-art imaging and analytical capability of a high-resolution field emission SEM with nanometer-scale material removal, processing, and imaging capability of a FIB. Coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and electron backscatter diffraction detectors, the system permits high resolution chemical and crystallographic analysis of advanced materials. The FIB capability has enabled tomographic imaging and analysis of metals, ceramics, polymers, and biological materials (e.g. 3D imaging of multi-enzyme complexes that mediate microbial cell attachment for efficient biomass degradation). The FIB-SEM has supported research in nanomaterials, biomaterials, functional materials, advanced metals processing, solid-state batteries, plant science, biofilms, advanced coatings/thin films, anti-counterfeiting technology, geoscience, and energy resources. Since the system was made available to users in the Spring of 2022, a total of 105 users have completed training and collected data on the FIB-SEM, and the system serves as the most widely used research instrument on campus. Trained users have included undergraduate students, graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, research staff, and faculty. In addition, equipment usage has been supported by >45 different funded research projects. In total the system has supported 37 peer reviewed journal publications, one book chapter, 14 PhD/MS thesis/dissertations, 45 national/international conference presentations, and 18 regional conference presentations (all undergraduate/graduate student 1st author). In addition, the system has been used to support two NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) programs (#2150356, #1852336) and an NSF National Research Traineeship (NRT) program (#1828462).

Broader Impacts

The FIB-SEM has complemented previous MRI-funded equipment acquisitions that together comprise a growing state-of-the-art materials characterization multi-user facility (EMES) that has positively impacted SDSMT’s ability to competitively recruit talented faculty and students from underrepresented groups in STEM. The new FIB-SEM system has directly supported eight PhD programs and nine undergraduate programs at SD Mines. The programs/students have used the system for both research and educational (e.g., courses and engineering design projects) activities. Regarding educational impact, the requested instrument has been implemented in a variety of courses comprising all degree programs (first year BS through PhD) and multiple disciplines. For instance, it was integrated into the Metallurgical Engineering Senior (MET 465) and Junior Design (MET 352) courses where it was used to characterize various metallic and ceramic materials in support of students’ engineering design projects. It was also included as a laboratory module in the Properties of Materials Laboratory (MET 231) course where sophomore students gained their first exposure to electron microscopy and advanced materials characterization. In addition, the system was used to support an electron microscopy and microchemical analysis module in GEOL 624L Analytical Methods in Geochemistry. The system was also used to support the course Scanning Electron Microscopy (GEOL 656L). Finally, a new course entitled, MES 656L - Introduction to SEM and FIB was developed through this program and has quickly become an “in demand” course that will be delivered each year. Through the award period, a total of 445 students have gained exposure to the FIB-SEM system through various laboratory and engineering design courses that used the system.

Operations, training, and maintenance of the system has been managed by the Engineering and Mining Experiment Station (EMES). Established in 1903, EMES is a centralized multi-user instrumentation facility that is available to South Dakota researchers and regional companies. The FIB-SEM represents the flagship instrument and most heavily utilized system within the EMES. The EMES provides analytical services for outside government, industry, and academic organizations. In addition, the EMES has an established track record of supporting national, regional, and local technology-based economic development. Past users include Tribal Colleges/NA Tribes (e.g., Oglala Lakota College, Rosebud Sioux Tribe), national companies, with the majority being local, tech-based, start-up companies. During the award period a total of eight local companies have used the system to support their research and development activities. Thus, we expect the newly acquired FIB-SEM to provide a lasting impact on economic development in the Black Hills region and the state of South Dakota.


Last Modified: 12/31/2024
Modified by: Grant A Crawford
